segments.text: With Mr. Evans on the 11th of April, 1999,
the anniversary of the first shots at Fort Sumter
that started the Civil War in 1861.
Happened to read the paper today.
The weather outside in Brackettville today is cloudy,
but on the inside is bright and sunny.
Let's see, we were chatting about the beginning of your agricultural work
and your ranching.
When did you first go into the land business for yourself?
Five dollars an acre?
Now you say the Brown brothers.
Is this Herman and George Brown in Houston?
How long had you known them?
That land that...
Up in the panhandle,
did it by chance have any oil underneath it?
Thirteen years, never failed to make a profit.
And what were you growing?
Now your favorite cattle are red.
Now you've been both in ranching and farming.
What was your favorite crop?
Which crop did you enjoy growing most?
Now when did you acquire the Nine Bar Ranch?
What year?
What time?
And kept it how long?
What were the joys of being in the farm and ranching business?
What did you enjoy most?
If you were buying land today,
if I were buying land and came to you for advice,
where would you tell me to look at land most closely?
Where in Texas?
Out here?
When did you buy this land?
14,000 acres.
Okay.
Do you run cattle on it?
Sheep?
What kind of cattle?
Senator Gertrude.
Let's go back to Texas A&M.
You worked with President Gilchrist.
Describe his accomplishments, his goals in the highway department.
Was he a big man physically?
Who was it that decided he was the one to bring to A&M?
Do you know?
Because he came as dean of engineering and then became president.
Was he easy to work with?
Who was the executive director of the former students then?
Trying to remember who was leading the former students in those years.
I don't either.
And let's see.
And Dr. Harrington was coming up on the faculty.
Did you remain in connection with him after you finished as a student?
And did he and Ruth Harrington get married soon after his college days?
She's still living there in Bryan.
Okay.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
